head.supplied: 22/6/90. ¶ ¶ Let me say, dear Prof. Tate, that your goodeniac. plant N. 1 from Cox's peninsula ¶ is Calogyne purpurea in a larger state, than that, from which the species became originally establish...

div.p: Barr Smith Library, University of Adelaide, South Australia.

Let me say, dear Prof. Tate, that your goodeniac. plant N. 1 from Cox's peninsula
NT. is Calogyne purpurea in a larger state, than that, from which the species became originally established. You may have ascertained this already yourself; but as I am just describing some few novelties from Holtze's later collections, I found this now out, he having sent a still more divergent form.

I shall on this occasion attend to some few more of your plants from Arnhem's Land.
NT.

Of the Helipterum Fitzgibboni I have sent a diagnosis with some other descriptions to the "Vict. Naturalist," as the dedication was to a Vict. Gentleman long ago.
B90.07.02. The plant was named in honour of the long-serving Town Clerk of Melbourne, E. G. FitzGibbon. I have however already used from the msc., sent to you, the dedicatory words, so that the whole rest of the notes on that Helipterum would remain original as a suppl. for our essay.
I hope, you were pleased with the lithograms of the Babbagias.
Did you give up the Kochia pentatropis?

div.p: I wrote before that the Potamogeton was not P. natans, but that in the absense of fruit it could not be named. The incessent interruptions here bring me sometimes as a phytographer almost to despair! Have you any good specimens of Blyxa from S. Australia?

The Good.
Goodenia? from Pine-Creek is also a Calogyne, it may be an other variety
